content:
I am impressed by your success at moving your thousands of messages from Agent to your Local Folders folder.

But I don't understand how you moved an account's contents from a server that only supports POP, and you did the transfer in IMAP. Or was "Agent" your email client (software), and your server (provider) an IMAP server?

If Agent only supported POP, how did it happen to have copies of your messages available?

And the big question: Why in the world would you move perfectly good messages from a secure folder on your computer INTO an IMAP-connected INBOX, when the IMAP server is only prepared to have messages in your INBOX that originated from the current server?

I'm just plain confused, and hoping to get some clarification from you.
creator: danawilson001

content:
I'm having trouble imagining what you're seeing.

When you click Reply, is the main window set to full screen? Have you tried clicking the two-box icon just to the left of the X at the top right of your window, and then moving the edges of the reduced-size window to try to see the Reply window behind it?

Another idea occurred to me: With your main window open and a message selected, click the Reply button, and then if the Reply window is not right in front, minimize the main window by clicking the dash at the top of the window, to the left of the Full-screen/restored-size button. That will reveal any window that's hiding behind your main window.
creator: danawilson001

content:
Hello @wisewiz

Sorry, have tried both of those as well as right click to move/re-size the reply window. None worked.
creator: davidmcdermit

content:
I've never seen this in Thunderbird, but here's a tip: If a window seems to be hidden behind another window, you can re-size the front-most window by dragging an edge of it until you can see the hind-most window peeking out, and tap on the hindmost. It will come to the fore.

A lot depends on your sizing of your windows. You'll have little annoyances to cope with if you insist on running programs in full-screen mode. Make your TBird window occupy a smaller portion of your screen, and then click Reply, and make your Reply window occupy a slightly larger portion of your screen than the main window.

That'll do it.

Another trick you can use (when you have a window open and then you open another window that comes to the front) is press the Alt key and tap the Tab key. That'll switch the rear to the front and the front to the rear, and doing it again will do it again. <smile>
creator: danawilson001

content:
Riguardo alle tue ipotesi: - Problemi di rete: potrebbe essere ma è un caso abbastanza raro a meno che la tua connessione non sia molto instabile o molto lenta. Te ne accorgeresti però anche navigando di problemi del genere. - Problemi al server: è di solito il motivo più comune: se il server è sovraccarico o tarda molto a rispondere alle richieste di Thunderbird (generando un errore di 'tempo scaduto') oppure chiude le connessioni che non riesce a gestire con l'errore di disconnessione che hai mostrato sopra. Purtroppo a poterti rispondere in merito è solo il tuo fornitore.

Questo tipo di problemi sono più frequenti con le connessioni IMAP in cui il client rimane costantemente collegato al server. Se non hai bisogno di IMAP, potresti passare a POP3 che si connette in maniera differente e solo a certi intervalli di tempo. Qui è spiegata la differenza tra i due protocolli -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/differenze-imap-pop3

content: First, I hope you backed up the profile when Thunderbird was not running. That is important. Otherwise, the profile will likely be corrupt. Second, try letting Thunderbird do the work. Try tools>import>import from another installation.
creator: davidsk

content: Try this: - settings>general scroll down to config editor and open it - search for network.protocol-handler.warn-external.http and set to true - search also for network.protocol-handler.warn-external.https and set to true - save and exit - open a link with a URL. At the popup, click 'choose' and select your preferred browser.
creator: davidsk

content:
I understand you point but from a tracking in an email thread, it is good to see "all" the infomration and not jsut the sender of the email. For example. Do a "Reply All", you do not get all te inidivdual whe were on the origninal email chain. If you click forward on the message, you see the entire header.

This is also the reason all other email clients I have ever used, provide the entire header in the reply. I have had numberous situation where I had to pull back up email archives to identify oter recipiants on an email chain.

With the current menthod, you would have to go back to the orgiianl email received to see all receipenats. This is important if indiviudal were removed as well.

To just say that the sender is te only relevant individual in the email chain doe snot makes sense. Especially when you hit forward and Thrunderid has the information present.

As I stated before, i wil send in a feature request. It is just wild that every other email client provides this infomation.
creator: jcarrington

content:
A 'Reply' usually means reply to sender, so headers are generally considered as not required as the sender already knows that information because they sent the email.

Not sure what settings you are using but I have the following. Settings > General scroll to bottom and click on 'Config Editor' to see 'Advanced Preferences' in new tab

I set the following:

  • mailnews.reply_header_ondateauthorwrote = On #2#3, #1 wrote
  • mailnews.reply_header_type = 2

When I click on 'Reply' it says something like this: On date time sender wrote:

This says who sent original and the date and time of original email. The Subject is already included in the 'Subject' as 'Re: subject'

That offers most of the basic header information without needing an addon.

Actually - I wanted a line separating the original message and my response, but you cannot do this in the config editor but you can do it in the 'prefs.js' file. so I did this:

Located profile folders. Exit Thunderbird Open 'prefs.js' file using Notepad

Then located this line: user_pref("mailnews.reply_header_ondateauthorwrote", "On #2 #3, #1 wrote:");

Then modified it to say the following: user_pref("mailnews.reply_header_ondateauthorwrote", "_________________________________________________________________________________________ \On #2 #3, #1 wrote:");

Saved the file and started Thunderbird. So now when I click on 'Reply'

I see my reponse on top with Signature. Followed by a line - it is reasonably wide but does not expand with window. 3 escaped lines On date time sender wrote:

see example in image
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
The add-on is compatible with the current release, 102. Whether or not it will be updated for the next release is a matter for the add-on author to decide. Despite the likely availability of TB 115 next month, it will probably not be recommended for widespread release for several months.

You can submit a Request For Enhancement at Bugzilla if the feature isn't in the next release (it isn't in the current 115 beta).
creator: sfhowes
